blocks.title: Requirements Analysis
blocks.content: The concept of a Digital Twin is very broad. Many definitions co-exist. When developing new Digital Twin applications, the first step is always to define the user stories. Which processes and which users does the Digital Twin need to support?

components.subtitle: Consultancy
components.text: Consultants are the first to come into action when a new Digital Twin project is started. The consultant determines the requirements and wishes of the client and translates them into a clear project plan and data-driven approach. The requirements analysis defines what data and information are required and what functionalities and tools need to be developed.

components.subtitle: UX Design
components.text: Based on the wishes, a User Experience (UX) design can be made to make a general outline for the portal to be developed. The design focusses on the needs and expectations of the end users in order to provide a relevant experience to the users. The input from the consultants is central to create a design that is intuitive and easy to use.

blocks.title: Open Data
blocks.content: Data forms the foundation of a Digital Twin. With the input from the requirements analysis, we can determine what data is needed. Open source datasets often play an important role. These data are freely available to the public without restrictions or costs. Many governments and research institutions provide open data to stimulate research and innovation. Open data is extremely valuable to save time and costs when developing a Digital Twin.

components.subtitle: Key Registers
components.text: The Netherlands has large amounts of high-quality open data available thanks to the Key Registers. The PDOK (Publieke Dienstverlening Op de Kaart) is the central platform for open geospatial data in the Netherlands.

components.subtitle: European Data Portal
components.text: The European Data Portal aggregates open data from European countries, providing access to datasets related to various sectors, including transportation, environment, and public services.

components.subtitle: NASA/ESA
components.text: NASA and ESA offer Earth observation datasets with high-quality imagery and geospatial data related to climate, land cover, and more.

blocks.title: Data Collection
blocks.content: Open data is not always sufficient to satify the user requirements. Extra data many need to be collected to create an accurate and up-to-date geospatial database that can be used to deploy the Digital Twin. The data collection may involve field surveys or other specialized tools.

components.subtitle: Field surveys
components.text: Field surveys are a common method to collect geospatial data. Field workers can use GPS devices and other tools to collect data in the field.

components.subtitle: Sensors
components.text: IoT sensors can be used to collect real-time data from the environment. Sensors can be used to monitor air quality, temperature, humidity, noise, and other environmental factors. The data collected by the sensors can be used to create a real-time representation of the environment in the Digital Twin.

components.subtitle: Archives
components.text: Archives and historical data can be used to analyze changes in the environment over time and to predict future trends. Organizations often have large data archives that are not publicly available, but can be used to enrich the Digital Twin.

blocks.title: Technical Platform
blocks.content: The technical platform is the core for running the Digital Twin with all data integrated. It consists of various software components to manage tasks like data storage, data processing tools and data management. These software components are the building blocks of the Digital Twin infrastructure.

components.subtitle: Hosting & Deployment
components.text: The building blocks of the Digital Twin infrastructure are hosted on a single cloud platform. The cloud environment provides the resources and ensures the scalability of the platform - it dynamically adapts as the amount of data grows. Hosting of the Sogelink Digital Twin is organized via the Google Cloud. The building blocks are deployed in so-called indepdent containers. Containerization prevents conflicts between different software components and ensures that the software runs consistently.

components.subtitle: Open source
components.text: The Digital Twin infrastructure is built on open-source software. Open-source software is software with a source code that anyone can inspect, modify and enhance. Open-source software is flexible and can be adapted to the specific needs of the project. The Sogelink Digital Twin platform is built on open-source software, including PostgreSQL, PostGIS, CesiumJS, and Docker.

components.subtitle: Open standards
components.text: Data standards are an essential pillar for efficiently operating a Digital Twin. Standards allows for producing data that can be used widely and reliably. There are standards for data formats, metadata, data catalogs and data exchange. The Digital Twin infrastructure is built on open standards to ensure that the data and services are interoperable and can be used across different systems.

components.subtitle: Security
components.text: Protecting the data and ensuring the security and privacy of sensitive information are important. The platform includes security features to protect against cyber threats and unauthorized access. User roles can be created to manage who can access which parts of the data and infrastructure. This allows us to comply with the ISO standards for digital security.

blocks.title: Data Storage
blocks.content: Digital Twinning is all about data - and the data needs to be stored somewhere. Databases are used to store the data that we have collected our data. There are many different types of databases, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. The choice of database depends on the type of data and the desired use. The Sogelink Digital Twin is equipped with a number of different databases to store and manage the data in an appropiate way.

components.subtitle: Object Storage
components.text: Data can be saved in files. Think about images or text based files such as txt, csv or json. Such files are stored in so-called cloud storage buckets. The storage buckets can be used to store and retrieve data files and are flexible to scale up or down. File storage is often referred to as 'object storage' or 'blob storage'.

components.subtitle: Relational data
components.text: Data in a table-like format is stored in relational databases. When talking about relation data, you can think about building details, subsurface models or tree locations.PostgreSQL is an open-source database system for storing the relational geospatial data in the Sogelink Digital Twin. Relational databases are used in combination with Structured Query Language (SQL) to add, delete and edit the data.

components.subtitle: Real-time data
components.text: Real-time data is data that is continuously collected and processed by sensors. Examples of real-time data sources are traffic or weather data. Real-time data is often used in Digital Twins to provide live information about the physical environment. The quantities of real-time data can be huge and proper data handling is crucial. The Sogelink Digital Twin makes use of DuckDB and Parquet files to manage real-time data. Parquet is a columnar storage format that is optimized to query large real-time datasets.

blocks.title: Data Processing Tools
blocks.content: We have our technical platform ready and collected a bunch of data. Now it is time to shape the data to feed the Digital Twin. A data-driven approach is all about getting as much value from the data as possible. One way to do this is by combining the existing data sources to create new datasets. Also, it is possible to apply modelling and machine learning techniques to extract new information from exisiting data. Reworking data in a smart way can provide greater contex and insights into the available data.

components.subtitle: Data fusion
components.text: Data fusion involves bringing together data from different sources. The goal is to combine the data to create new datasets with added value. Data fusion can be performed in many different ways. An example is our 3D Buildings dataset, where point cloud data are combined with building footprints to create 3D models of buildings.

components.subtitle: AI and Machine learning
components.text: Machine learning (ML) is gaining importance in the world of Geo-IT to analyze large amounts of data. Machine learning is a type of Artificial Intelligence (AI) that enables computers to learn without being explicitly programmed. Machine learning algorithms can learn from data and make predictions based on what they have learned. For example, machine learning can be used to detect objects in images or to predict future events based on historical data. For example, ML can be used detect windows from aerial imagery and add this information to a building dataset.

components.subtitle: Predictive Modelling
components.text: Modelling is performed to simulate and predict the behavior of a system. Models are basically (complex) calculations that can be used to test different scenarios under different conditions. For example, models can be used to predict the stability of infrastructural assets under different stress scenarios. In the context of smart cities, AI models can be use to predict fluxes of people in public transport and traffic.

components.subtitle: 3D Data Conversion
components.text: For visualization, data is processed to 3D. PostGIS is one of the most used software in the Sogelink Digital Twin platform to achieve this. Sogelink Research has developed custom tooling to process data from a PostgreSQL database directly into standardized 3D data formats, including pg2b3dm and i3dm.export.

blocks.title: Extract, Transform, Load
blocks.content: Within the Digital Twin infrastructure, there is a lot of data tranfer. Data is retrieved from the source, stored in the database and processed. The results are then again stored in the database. Often, there are multiple data processing steps to prepare the data. The entire data processing pipeline is often referred to as ETL: Extract, Transform, Load.

components.subtitle: Standard data formats
components.text: Standardization is important to ensure that the data is consistent and can be used across the entire platform. For the data formats, data processing tools are aligned with international standards. Many of the geodata standards are maintained by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC). Data format standardization facilitates interoperability between the data processing tools and the Digital Twin platform and streamlines the ETL processes.

components.subtitle: Georeferencing
components.text: There is an endless number of coordinate systems. It is important to align the data to the same coordinate system (i.e. georeference) to ensure that the data can be used together. GDAL is a popular open-source library for geospatial data processing. GDAL is useful to convert data to other coordinate systems (and formats).

components.subtitle: Automatized ETL pipelines
components.text: ETL can be complex, since required input and output can differ per data processing tool. Automating the ETL processes helps to prevent mistakes and keep the data up to date. Mage is a tool that we have implemented to automate ETL processes. With Mage, you can make an complete pipeline that extracts data from a source, transforms it into a format that is suitable for the target system, and then loads it into the target system. It can also be used to schedule pipelines at regular intervals to keep the data up-to-dat and ready for use.

blocks.title: Data Management
blocks.content: As the amount of data increases, it is easy to lose the overview. Data management aims at keeping track of the data quality, reliability and other metdata. Data management helps to keep the data well-organized and easy to find by different people. When a user sees data in the digital, he wants to know where the data is coming from and what the quality is.

components.subtitle: Data Management System
components.text: Datasets are registered in a catalog. The catalog provides an overview of all the datasets that are available in the Digital Twin. The catalog is used to search for datasets and to find information about the datasets. CKAN is used in the Sogelink Digital Twin platform to register data.

components.subtitle: Metadata
components.text: Metadata are data about data. Metadata describe datasets and provide information about its content, licenses, quality and structure. Metadata are essential to keep track of the data and to ensure that the data is reliable and can be used by different people. ISO 19115 is a widely used standard for geospatial metadata.

blocks.title: APIs and Services
blocks.content: We can store, process and manage our data. Yet, that does not mean that it magically apears in the Digital Twin. The final step in the data phase is serving the data, that is, making the data available. The method to serve data depends on the storage location, data format and desired end use. Data can be made accessible through web servers, database connections, web services or other APIs. An API is a piece of software that allows applications to communicate and exchange data between each other.

components.subtitle: Web API
components.text: Functionalities of the data processing tools can be embedded in a web framework and made available over HTTP. In this way, for example, modelling algortihms can be accessed directly from the web so that end-users can runs simulations on-the-fly.

components.subtitle: Database API
components.text: Databases can also be queried directly from the web. PostGraphile and pg_featureserv are APIs to communicate with PostgreSQL databases. The custom Sogelink Research tool GoParquet was dveelopped to query Parquet files via DuckDB. These database APIs make it possible to directly execute SQL functions on the database to retrieve data in a targeted way, for example for a specific geographic location.

components.subtitle: OGC Web Map Services
components.text: OGC Web Map Services (WMS) and Web Map Tiled Services (WMTS) are standard protocols developed by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) for sharing 2D map layers over the internet. WMS are WMTS are the most widely used services in GIS systems and provide a standardized way for clients to request and receive map images from remote servers. GeoServer is an open-source server for publishing geospatial data as web services.

components.subtitle: Tiled Map Services
components.text: There are several alternatives to serve map layers, including Cloud Optimized GeoTIFF (COG), MBTiles and PMTiles. These solutions are used to serve map layers in a scalable and cost-effective way without the need to manage server-side functions.

components.subtitle: OGC SensorThings API
components.text: The OGC SensorThings API is a standard for providing access to IoT sensor data. The SensorThings API is a standard developed by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) to provide an open and unified way to interconnect IoT devices and applications over the web. FROST is an open-source implementation of the SensorThings API. FROST can be used to serve real-time sensor data in the Sogelink Digital Twin platform.

components.subtitle: Catalog APIs
components.text: Data within a catalog can also be made available through web services. The web services provide an interface to search for datasets and to retrieve metadata. Catalog web services are used to integrate the catalog into the Digital Twin and to make the data available to other users.

blocks.title: Map Viewer
blocks.content: We have produced the necessary data and deployed the services to serve the data. Everything is set for rolling out the Digital Twin user portal. Since the datacore complies with open data standards, we can connect it with numerous front-end platforms. Map visualizations are a powerful way to present geospatial data. The possibilities to do this in 3D via web applications continue to improve.

components.subtitle: CesiumJS
components.text: CesiumJS is an open-source software library for creating 3D globes and maps in the web browser. CesiumJS is primarily known for its capabilities in rendering geospatial data in 3D, making it a powerful tool for creating Digital Twin visualizations. CesiumJS is the core software within the Sogelink Digital Twin front-end platform to create the base canvas that integrates both 2D and 3D geospatial data.

components.subtitle: MapLibre
components.text: Other mapping libraries often also have 3D capabilities. For example, MapLibre is an open-source JavaScript library for interactive maps and is suited when complex 3D functionalities are not required. MapLibre has more limited 3D support, but is more performant for 2D map and vector data.

components.subtitle: User interface
components.text: The map viewer is equipped with a user interface that allows users to interact with the map viewer. The user interface provides tools to navigate the map, add and remove layers, set bookmarks and perform basic measurements. The user interface is built with SvelteKit, a framework for building web applications. Per project, specific modules may be developed and added to the user interface to meet the requirements of the project.

blocks.title: 3D Tiles
blocks.content: An important standard for optimized 3D data visualization is the OGC 3D Tiles standard. 3D Tiles is an open standard for streaming massive 3D geospatial datasets over the internet. The standard is actively being developed by the Cesium team and officially supported by the OGC (Open Geospatial Consortium). 3D Tiles is designed to efficiently organize and transmit large 3D datasets.

components.subtitle: GLB/glTF
components.text: 3D Tiles are built on GLB/glTF files. GLB (GL Binary) and glTF (GL Transmission Format) are open standard file formats designed for 3D models and scenes. They are often used in computer graphics, 3D modeling and virtual/augmented reality.

components.subtitle: Batched 3D Models
components.text: Batched 3D models are a common data type in our Digital Twins. Batched 3D models are collections of individual 3D models, representing structures or objects with non-uniform shapes, such as buildings. We have developed the tool pg2b3dm to convert 3D models from a PostgreSQL database to the 3D Tiles format.

components.subtitle: Instanced 3D Models
components.text: Instanced 3D models consist of instances or repetitions of a single 3D model. Think of it as a single 3D model duplicated multiple times, often used for objects or elements with consistent shapes, such as streetlights or trees. We have developed the tool i3dm.export to convert 3D models from a PostgreSQL database to the 3D Tiles format.

components.subtitle: Point Clouds
components.text: Point clouds are a common data type in our Digital Twins. Point clouds are collections of points that represent the surface of an object or area. Point clouds are typically generated by 3D scanners or LiDAR sensors. Point clouds are stored in various file formats, including LAS, LAZ, PLY, and XYZ. Point clouds can be converted to 3D Tiles using tools like GoCesiumTiler or Oslandia's py3dtiles.

components.subtitle: BIM models
components.text: Building Information Models (BIM) are used in the construction industry to create digital representations of buildings and infrastructure. BIM models can be converted to 3D Tiles using a tool like pg2b3dm, but often require specialized pre-processing to ensure correct georeferencing.

blocks.title: 3D Terrain
blocks.content: 3D Terrain is essential in a geospatial Digital Twin visualization. A Digital Elevation Model (DEM) holds elevation data and is typically the starting point for a 3D terrain. DEMs are usually provided in GeoTIFF or ASC files. The elevation data usually requires pre-processing to account for gaps (e.g. on water surfaces) or irregularities.

components.subtitle: Quantized mesh
components.text: A DEM can be processed into a triangulated 3D mesh. A quantized 3D mesh is a special type of 3D mesh that is suited for streaming massive terrain datasets for 3D visualization. Cesium Terrain Builder is a useful tool to make such quantized terrain meshes from GeoTIFF data.

components.subtitle: Cesium Terrain on Demand
components.text: Terrain data can be huge, especially when applying Digital Twinning on a national or international level. To prevent the need to store and process large terrain datasets in advance, Sogelink developed Cesium Terrain on Demand. This Web API service allows to generate quantized mesh terrain tiles on demand from a Cloud Optimized GeoTIFF (COG) file.

blocks.title: Physical Living Environment
blocks.content: Using open data sources, we can create a 3D visualization of the physical living environment that functions as a base canvas for the Digital Twin map viewer. The physical living environment can include buildings, roads, waterways, trees and other physical objects. Depending on the country, the available open data sources may vary.

blocks.title: Real-Time Insights
blocks.content: Visualizing data in 3D is nice, but we are not yet at the level of a Digital Twin. Apart from looking like the real world, a Digital Twin should also behave like the real world. From a data perspective, sensor data and the Internet of Things (IoT) can help to make the environment dynamic and bring the Digital Twin to life. Real-time data enable users to monitor the state of the environment in real-time and respond to changes as they happen. We are icnreasingly implementing the time dimension into our Digital Twin.

components.subtitle: Traffic and Parking places Nantes
components.text: For the city of Nantes, we have visualized the traffic and parking situation in real-time. This integration provides real-time insights into traffic flows and parking availability.

components.subtitle: Ship Transponder data (AIS)
components.text: The locations of ships on the water networks are continuously tracked via an automatic identification system (AIS). The AIS data can be used to visualize the current location of ships in the Digital Twin. A time slider allows for displaying ship movements through time. The AIS data can also be used to predict the future location of ships, which is used to simulate the impact of ships on the water network.

components.subtitle: Ground water levels
components.text: The ground water table is a key factor for dike stability. Ground water levels are continuously measured in monitoring wells to monitor the current situation. The sensor data from monitoring wells can be used to provide insights into the real-time and past ground water levels.

blocks.title: Prediction and Simulation
blocks.content: Within the Digital Twin, we can show the current situation and display dynamic changes in the system through time. Displaying data on the map and through time is not always enough. To gain even deeper insight, the Digital Twin infrastructure can also be used to simulate different scenarios and make predictions.

components.subtitle: Subsurface Models
components.text: circulaire grondstromen

components.subtitle: Flood Barrier Stability
components.text: tki

blocks.title: BIM-GIS
blocks.content: An application where both real-time and predictive modelling is combined is asset management. The Digital Twin can be used to monitor the state of assets in real-time and predict the future state of assets. The Digital Twin can be used to support decision-making by providing insights into the impact of different scenarios.

components.subtitle: Road Infrastructure
components.text: Moerdijkbrug

blocks.title: Multi-Criteria Analysis
blocks.content: Users are able to control the Digital Twin to make decisions and take actions. The Digital Twin can be used to support decision-making by providing insights into the impact of different scenarios. For example, the Digital Twin can be used to compare different design options or tweak parameters.

components.subtitle: Spatial Planning (NOVEX)
components.text: NOVEX is a tool that is used to support spatial planning. NOVEX is used to visualize and analyze spatial data in the Digital Twin. NOVEX provides a user-friendly interface to create and manage spatial plans. The plans can be used to visualize complex data and facilitate interactive analyses.

blocks.title: Dashboards
blocks.content: Since the Digital Twin infrastructure adheres to open standards, it is not limited to 3D visualization applications. A Digital Twin is not equal to a 3D viewer. Other analytical applications such as interactive dashboards can be connected to the Digital Twin infrastructure for complex data analyses. Multiple applications can also be used in parallel to support different user stories.

components.subtitle: Smart City Monitor
components.text: Jupyter Notebooks are an interactive environment for running code and showing the results. Such analytical notebooks were used extensively in the Smart City project in Den Bosch and Breda.

components.subtitle: Cousteau
components.text: Cousteau is a dashboarding tool that is used to visualize and analyze data in the Digital Twin. Cousteau provides a user-friendly interface to create and manage dashboards. The dashboards can be used to visualize complex data and facilitate interactive analyses.
